discharge_summary: date of admission: 10/04 on d11 of i mcbad and d5 of filgrastim d1 on 09/24 date of discharge: 11/03 reason for admission: treatment of bacterial and fungal endocarditis. admission: 10/04/2022, discharge: 11/04/2022, stay: 01 m 23 h, location: ward, payer: sus. case report: refractory multiple myeloma iga lambda a vi vcd iss without b2mgb/ds iiia diagnosis {omitted} relapse: anemia elevated iga and lambda pleural effusion with cytology 41% atypical plasma cells extramedullary plasmacytoma abdomen and pleura pleural biopsy 04/22: cells with scant eosinophilic cytoplasm and small, round, hyperchromatic nuclei at the cell periphery. ihq: strong and demarcated expression of cd 56, cd 138, and lambda plasmacytoid differentiation. kappa. ki67: 95%. diagnosis: plasmacytoma, multiple myeloma. abdominal biopsy 04/22: plasma cells infiltrating skeletal muscle tissue. frequent mitotic figures. no necrosis. ihq: cd138, cd56, lambda, kappa. pmo 04/16/21: diluted in sp. sv hypocellular. sb normocellular with preserved maturation. sm megakaryocytes absent in smear bmo 04/16: 35% cellularity. no neoplastic infiltration in the sample. tomography myeloma protocol 02/15/2022: awaiting report transthoracic echocardiography 04/22: ejection fraction 65% mild tricuspid regurgitation, psap 47. 2020 serologies: negative ecog: 1 previous chemotherapies: i vtd pace 07/31/2020 vi vtd d1 10/07/2020 to d1 03/10/2021 while awaiting krd disease progression previous therapeutic schedule krd total of xviii cycles [person]: performed v cycles, with disease progression emergence of plasmacytomas new treatment schedule, as discussed with [person] on 10/23: performance of mcbad for 2 to 2 cycles, while defining a new therapy. d1 i mcbad 09/24. examinations carried out during hospitalization: head tomography 05/10 done in the context of lowered level of consciousness, thrombocytopenia, bleeding ruled out. transthoracic echocardiography 10/08: preserved LVSD subjective s 8 pp 8 LVDD 45 it mild psap 50 mmhg rectification of the septum in the shape of a d extracardiac structure compressing the left atrium moderately depressed RVSD fac 20% transthoracic echocardiography 10/19: fe 62% LVDD 46 s 9.5 pp 9 filamentous images adhered to the atrial face measuring the largest 4 mm suggestive of mild IM vegetation, cultures: blood culture 10/04: staphylococcus mitis 2 samples blood culture 10/08: candida tropicalis sensitive to ketoconazole and amphotericin B micafungin and caspofungin not tested, blood culture 10/12: staphylococcus epidermidis 1 sample after 43 hours considered as a contaminant, antibiotic therapy used: cefepime: 10/04 10/05. escalated to 11/05 due to growth of streptococcus mittis in blood culture on 11/04 meropenem 10/05 10/20 vancomycin 10/05 11/03 micafungin 10/10 evaluation of other specialties: in medical records. I performed reassessment tests for the disease on the day of hospital discharge. I prescribe SLOK K 1 tablet every 12 hours. Please, whoever evaluates her at the blood center, checks the need to maintain replacement, advises warning signs and to contact the [organization] team if necessary. I request a purchase order for vorizonazole for secondary prophylaxis as instructed by the [organization] team. I schedule a transesophageal echocardiogram for 11/24. I leave pending tests to monitor eosinophilia and GGT changes, atrial fibrillation that, together with the rash presented after vancomycin on 10/31, raised the diagnostic hypothesis of DRESS syndrome by the dermatologist. Despite this hypothesis, [person] showed complete improvement of the rash and a decrease in the eosinophil count. Therefore, we opted for discharge due to low clinical suspicion at the time. I performed reassessment tests for the disease on the day of hospital discharge. hospitalization summary: [person] admitted on 10/04 on d11 of i mcbad d5 of [person] from [organization]. attended a consultation for clinical and laboratory evaluation after hospitalization 09/21 - 10/01. While waiting to be called for a consultation, she developed tremors and an increase in body temperature (pre-consultation temperature 35.6 during tremors 37.3). Due to neutropneic, she was admitted for treatment of febrile neutropenia with immediate initiation of cefepime. She was hospitalized from 09/21 to 10/01 due to dyspnea, when an extensive right lung lesion was identified, with extrinsic compression of the superior vena cava and right atrium. On September 24, the MCBAD regimen was initiated, but during the night of that date, he developed acute pulmonary edema (fluid overload), which resolved after noninvasive ventilation and furosemide. He remained in the intensive care unit for 3 days. He was discharged to the ward, and from there, to [address]. He underwent a control tomography on September 29, which showed complete resolution of compression and reduction of lung injury. After one day of hospitalization, on 10/05, she presented septic shock with need for vasoactive drugs and decreased level of consciousness, being referred to [organization], where she was hospitalized until 10/12. On 10/10, cultures with growth of yeast-like fungi were seen in blood culture 1 sample after 7:00 p.m. Candida tropicalis. Contacted [organization] and started on micafungin 100 mg 1x/day, as well as fungemia protocol, removal of central access and PIA devices, implantation of peripherally inserted central catheter and collection of catheter tip. In addition to abdominal and fundus ultrasound. The transthoracic echocardiogram showed no evidence of vegetations on examination. Therefore, transthoracic echocardiography was performed on 10/19 with the presence of filamentous images in the mitral valve suggestive of infectious vegetation, associated with mild mitral insufficiency, confirming the diagnostic hypothesis of bacterial and fungal endocarditis. Discussed with [person] from [organization] on 10/18, who advised to maintain micafungin because most Candida tropicalis are sensitive. Chest tomography was repeated on 10/18, showing control of multiple myeloma with extensive bone and right pleural disease, with disease stability in relation to 09/29 and pulmonary opacities including nodules, with the main suspicion of infectious alteration being septic embolism or fungal disease. In discussion with the [organization] team and rediscussed with [organization], we were advised to maintain antibiotics for 4 weeks from the start of treatment and not from the culture on 10/05/21 and antifungal for 6 weeks from 10/10/21. After the 6 weeks, repeat the echocardiogram and continue oral voriconazole for an indefinite period of time. Candida tropicalis is resistant to fluco and intermediate to voriconazole, given that there is no surgical plan for removal of vegetation of possible fungal etiology. On 10/31, the patient presented a skin rash with no hemodynamic repercussions and no warning signs. The hypothesis of Dress syndrome was raised, but [person] showed improvement on 11/4 with improvement in eosinophilia. discharged on 11/04/21, hemodynamically stable, eupneic, afebrile since 10/15, after finishing intravenous vancomycin with a schedule to follow-up appointment daily for infusion of micafungin 100 mg/day at the hospital on the scheduled end date of 11/21, as well as a scheduled follow-up appointment at [organization] for 11/08 to re-discuss the therapeutic schedule and arrange for the next lines of daratunumab chemotherapy.

On September 24, the MCBAD regimen was initiated, but during the night of that date, he developed acute pulmonary edema (fluid overload), which resolved after noninvasive ventilation and furosemide. Candida tropicalis is resistant to fluco and intermediate to voriconazole, given that there is no surgical plan for removal of vegetation of possible fungal etiology. question: ᱓᱑ ᱚᱠᱴᱳᱵᱚᱨ ᱦᱮᱡ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ, ᱟᱨ ᱤᱧ ᱟᱹᱰᱤᱧ ᱠᱩᱥᱤ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱾
answer: On October 31st, we found only one red spot on your body. It was considered a 'dress syndrome', but that red spot completely disappeared, and the eosinophil count decreased. Therefore, because the clinical suspicion was low, we decided to give you a chance.

question: ᱡᱚᱠᱷᱚᱱ ᱤᱧ ᱥᱮᱯᱴᱮᱢᱵᱚᱨ ᱨᱮ ᱥᱴᱨᱳᱠ ᱦᱩᱭᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱟᱨ ᱤᱧ ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞ ᱨᱮ ᱵᱷᱚᱨᱛᱤ ᱦᱩᱭᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱩᱱᱫᱚ ᱟᱢ ᱚᱠᱟᱨᱮᱢ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ ? ᱟᱢ ᱪᱮᱫ ᱤᱧᱮᱢ ᱰᱩᱵᱩᱡ ᱞᱮᱫᱤᱧᱟ ?
answer: ᱚᱠᱛᱚ ᱒᱐᱒᱔ ᱨᱮ, ᱩᱱᱤ ᱢᱤᱫᱴᱟᱝ ᱜᱟᱹᱦᱤᱨ ᱯᱞᱩᱢᱩᱱᱟᱨᱤ ᱮᱢᱵᱳᱞᱤᱡᱚᱢ (ᱢᱟᱭᱟᱢ ᱱᱟᱹᱞᱤ ᱨᱮ ᱡᱟᱸᱜᱮ ᱫᱟᱨᱟᱢ) ᱨᱮ ᱡᱷᱟᱵᱲᱟᱣ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ, ᱡᱟᱦᱟᱸ ᱛᱟᱭᱚᱢ ᱩᱱᱤ ᱫᱚ ᱵᱟᱝ ᱡᱟᱨᱯᱟᱣᱟᱱ ᱦᱚᱭ ᱪᱟᱞᱟᱣ ᱨᱮ ᱫᱚᱦᱚ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾

question: ᱪᱮᱫ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ ? ᱪᱮᱫ ᱤᱧᱟᱹᱜ ᱥᱟᱨᱡᱟᱨᱤ ᱵᱟᱝ ᱯᱩᱨᱟᱹᱣ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ ?

question: ᱦᱮ, ᱤᱧᱟᱹᱜ ᱠᱨᱤᱭᱮᱴᱤᱱᱤᱱ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱥᱛᱚᱨ ᱫᱚ ᱵᱮᱼᱥᱟᱵᱷᱟᱵᱤᱠ ᱜᱮᱭᱟ ᱥᱮ ? ᱰᱟᱭᱟᱞᱤᱥᱤᱥ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱞᱟᱹᱠᱛᱤ ᱢᱮᱱᱟᱜᱼᱟ ᱥᱮ ?
answer: ᱟᱢ ᱫᱚ 'ᱠᱤᱰᱱᱤ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱢᱟᱨᱮᱱ ᱟᱡᱟᱨ ᱥᱤᱠᱤᱰᱤᱼ᱓' (ᱡᱟᱦᱟᱸ ᱫᱚ ᱫᱚᱥᱟᱨ ᱫᱷᱟᱣ ᱛᱟᱭᱚᱢ ᱥᱮᱯᱥᱤᱥ ᱢᱮᱱᱛᱮ ᱢᱚᱱᱮᱭᱟᱜᱼᱟ) ᱮᱢ ᱪᱤᱱᱦᱟᱹᱣ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱾ ᱟᱢ ᱫᱚ ᱑᱑ ᱠᱷᱚᱱ ᱑᱓ ᱫᱷᱟᱹᱵᱤᱡ 'ᱠᱤᱰᱱᱤ ᱵᱚᱫᱚᱞ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱪᱤᱠᱤᱛᱥᱟ' (ᱰᱟᱭᱞᱤᱥᱤᱥ) ᱮᱢ ᱦᱟᱛᱟᱣ ᱮᱫ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱫ ᱾

discharge_summary: admission: 09/01/2020, discharge: 09/17/2020, stay: 16 d 13 h, location: ward, payer: SUS. A 67-year-old patient with a history of overweight, smoking, and major depression was admitted on 09/01 with a perforative acute abdomen, diagnosed after examinations. On the evening of 08/31, she sought care with abdominal pain, general malaise, and dyspnea. She had undergone hysterectomy on 08/30. On 09/01, she underwent exploratory laparotomy with a finding of intestinal perforation, with a suture of the lesion and placement of a peritoneostomy. She developed severe circulatory shock, probably due to peritonitis from contamination of the abdominal cavity, and antibiotic treatment was promptly started. She was re-addressed on 09/06, where an appendectomy and abdominal wall closure were performed. On 09/07, the patient's ventilatory status began to worsen, and a chest tomography scan was performed on 09/08, revealing low-load pulmonary embolism (5%) in addition to pneumonia. A multiresistant germ was isolated in a lung culture, with specific treatment directed at the patient. Given the clinical progression, a tracheostomy was indicated due to the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation. On 09/15, {omitted} prolonged cardiopulmonary arrest was reversed after approximately 20 minutes. The patient follow-up appointmented to the intensive care unit after the procedure, with mydriatic pupils and absence of reflexes. On 09/17, a computed tomography scan of the skull was performed, revealing anoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. Tests were performed to confirm brain death, which was confirmed on {omitted}. Perforating acute abdomen. 09/01: computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis: pneumoperitoneum, ascites, signs of peritonitis, parietal hyperalces and edema of the loops 09/01: computed tomography of the chest, pulmonary congestion, cardiomegaly, bilateral pleural effusion, opacities suggestive of an inflammatory or infectious process 09/08: computed tomography of the chest, pulmonary thromboembolism with 5% embolic burden 09/17: computed tomography of the skull. 09/01: exploratory laparotomy, sigmoid suture, creation of peritoneostomy 09/06: review, touch-ups on previous surgery with appendectomy and closure of the abdominal wall 09/15: tracheostomy 09/15: bilateral chest drainage. death.

discharge_summary: 1 severe acute respiratory syndrome, due to coronavirus. 2 new septic shock 01/14, fever hypotension, 3 acneiform eruption secondary to corticosteroid therapy, 4 pneumomediastinum airway injury? subcutaneous emphysema after depronation worsening ventilatory status, 5 new septic shock on 01/24 start of vasoactive drug, leukocytosis, 6 reactive adrenal insufficiency? hyperkalemia hyponatremia shock. admission: 01/06/2020, discharge: 03/03/2020, stay: 01 m 24 d 18 h, location: ward, payer: sus. clinical history [person] reports that he started with headache, myalgia and dry cough on 12/28, persisting with the same until 12/31, when he sought care and was prescribed prednisone, azithromycin, zinc and symptomatics. [person] started taking prescribed medications and on 02/01 he started with a fever, having performed a PCR for coronavirus with no result yet. On 03/01 he presented respiratory discomfort, having sought care on 04/01, when antibiotic therapy was changed to intravenous; the family member does not know which medication, however, there was no indication for hospital admission. [person] persisted with respiratory discomfort, having been hospitalized in the early hours of the same day. Emergency care unit report of oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, progressively worsening. He was admitted to the emergency unit on 06/01 with severe pulmonary involvement on chest x-ray, and was continued on antibiotic therapy initiated in the emergency care unit, ceftriaxone daily on 05/01 and prophylactic dexamethasone and enoxaparin initiated. He was admitted to [organization] on 07/01, requiring orotracheal intubation and central venous catheterization. He presented septic shock on 14/01, and his antibiotic regimen was changed. He remained in bed at [organization]. He developed new septic shock on 24/01, and began using fluconazole for fungal coverage. He developed pneumomediastinum on 26/01 due to airway injury, and underwent conservative treatment. He underwent tracheostomy on 29/01. He presented reactive adrenal insufficiency and acneiform rash related to corticosteroid therapy, in addition to diarrhea treated empirically with the hypothesis of pseudomembranous colitis. Acinetobacter baumanii was isolated in the tracheal aspirate, but was not treated due to the lack of clinical repercussion. He presented progressive clinical improvement and was transferred to [organization], where he remained stable. He underwent fibroscopy and was evaluated by speech therapy on 02/03, with no residual airway injury identified and a soft diet was released. He was decannulated on 03/03, remaining eupneic and in condition to be discharged. Good general condition, alert, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile, Glasgow 15, oxygen saturation 94% in room air with capped tracheostomy, respiratory rate 28 inspirations per minute, muscle strength grade 4 in upper and lower limbs, regular heart rhythm in two beats, normal sound sounds without murmurs. Heart rate 76, vesicular breath sounds present, symmetrical, without adventitious sounds, without use of accessory muscles. Flaccid, flat abdomen, painless to palpation, without masses or visceromegaly. Extremities: palpable peripheral pulses, without edema, absence of swelling of the calves. Presence of pressure ulcer in the left lower limb, without signs of infection. Tracheostomy fibroscopy. I advise [person] on outpatient follow-up visits for: head and neck surgery on 03/15 speech therapy on 03/25 reassessment of diet physiatry to be scheduled I advise [person] on home care for tracheostomy orifice, diet, exercise and care. I prescribe symptomatic medications. Aminc, head and neck surgery, speech therapy, physiatry. Good general condition, slim, conscious and oriented, moving all 4 limbs actively with grade 4 muscle strength, still not able to walk alone. Tracheostomy orifice occluded with dressing and eating a soft diet. No pain complaints.
question: ᱤᱧ ᱪᱮᱫ ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞᱤᱧ ᱪᱟᱞᱟᱜ ᱠᱟᱱᱟ ?
answer: 'ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱢᱮᱫ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱠᱚᱨᱳᱱᱟ ᱵᱷᱟᱭᱨᱟᱥ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱟᱱᱟᱴ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱾' ᱟᱢᱟᱜ 'ᱢᱮᱫ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱠᱚᱨᱳᱱᱟ ᱵᱷᱟᱭᱨᱟᱥ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱟᱱᱟᱴ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ,' ᱟᱨ 'ᱚᱲᱟᱜ ᱨᱮ ᱚᱠᱥᱤᱡᱮᱱ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱯᱚᱨᱤᱢᱟᱱ ᱘᱘% ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ, ᱵᱟᱹᱭ ᱵᱟᱹᱭᱛᱮ ᱠᱚᱢᱚᱜ ᱠᱟᱱ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱾'

discharge_summary: 1 severe acute respiratory syndrome, due to coronavirus. 2 new septic shock 01/14, fever hypotension, 3 acneiform eruption secondary to corticosteroid therapy, 4 pneumomediastinum airway injury? subcutaneous emphysema after depronation worsening ventilatory status, 5 new septic shock on 01/24 start of vasoactive drug, leukocytosis, 6 reactive adrenal insufficiency? hyperkalemia hyponatremia shock. admission: 01/06/2020, discharge: 03/03/2020, stay: 01 m 24 d 18 h, location: ward, payer: sus. clinical history [person] reports that he started with headache, myalgia and dry cough on 12/28, persisting with the same until 12/31, when he sought care and was prescribed prednisone, azithromycin, zinc and symptomatics. [person] started taking prescribed medications and on 02/01 he started with a fever, having performed a PCR for coronavirus with no result yet. On 03/01 he presented respiratory discomfort, having sought care on 04/01, when antibiotic therapy was changed to intravenous; the family member does not know which medication, however, there was no indication for hospital admission. [person] persisted with respiratory discomfort, having been hospitalized in the early hours of the same day. Emergency care unit report of oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, progressively worsening. He was admitted to the emergency unit on 06/01 with severe pulmonary involvement on chest x-ray, and was continued on antibiotic therapy initiated in the emergency care unit, ceftriaxone daily on 05/01 and prophylactic dexamethasone and enoxaparin initiated. He was admitted to [organization] on 07/01, requiring orotracheal intubation and central venous catheterization. He presented septic shock on 14/01, and his antibiotic regimen was changed. He remained in bed at [organization]. He developed new septic shock on 24/01, and began using fluconazole for fungal coverage. He developed pneumomediastinum on 26/01 due to airway injury, and underwent conservative treatment. He underwent tracheostomy on 29/01. He presented reactive adrenal insufficiency and acneiform rash related to corticosteroid therapy, in addition to diarrhea treated empirically with the hypothesis of pseudomembranous colitis. Acinetobacter baumanii was isolated in the tracheal aspirate, but was not treated due to the lack of clinical repercussion. He presented progressive clinical improvement and was transferred to [organization], where he remained stable. He underwent fibroscopy and was evaluated by speech therapy on 02/03, with no residual airway injury identified and a soft diet was released. He was decannulated on 03/03, remaining eupneic and in condition to be discharged. Good general condition, alert, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile, Glasgow 15, oxygen saturation 94% in room air with capped tracheostomy, respiratory rate 28 inspirations per minute, muscle strength grade 4 in upper and lower limbs, regular heart rhythm in two beats, normal sound sounds without murmurs. Heart rate 76, vesicular breath sounds present, symmetrical, without adventitious sounds, without use of accessory muscles. Flaccid, flat abdomen, painless to palpation, without masses or visceromegaly. Extremities: palpable peripheral pulses, without edema, absence of swelling of the calves. Presence of pressure ulcer in the left lower limb, without signs of infection. Tracheostomy fibroscopy. I advise [person] on outpatient follow-up visits for: head and neck surgery on 03/15 speech therapy on 03/25 reassessment of diet physiatry to be scheduled I advise [person] on home care for tracheostomy orifice, diet, exercise and care. I prescribe symptomatic medications. Aminc, head and neck surgery, speech therapy, physiatry. Good general condition, slim, conscious and oriented, moving all 4 limbs actively with grade 4 muscle strength, still not able to walk alone. Tracheostomy orifice occluded with dressing and eating a soft diet. No pain complaints.

question: ᱪᱮᱫ ᱫᱚ ᱥᱮᱯᱴᱤᱠ ᱥᱴᱨᱳᱠ ᱠᱟᱱᱟ ? ᱱᱚᱣᱟ ᱫᱚ ᱩᱱᱜᱮ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜᱼᱟ ᱡᱚᱠᱷᱚᱱ ᱡᱟᱦᱟᱭ ᱵᱟᱨᱭᱟ ᱥᱚᱝᱠᱨᱚᱢᱚᱱ ᱛᱮᱭ ᱡᱷᱟᱵᱲᱟᱜᱼᱟ ᱾
answer: ᱟᱢ ᱫᱚ ᱑᱔/᱐᱑ ᱨᱮ ᱥᱮᱯᱴᱤᱠ ᱥᱴᱨᱚᱠ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾ ᱟᱢ ᱫᱚ ᱒᱔/᱐᱑ ᱨᱮ ᱢᱤᱫᱴᱟᱝ ᱱᱟᱣᱟ ᱥᱮᱯᱴᱤᱠ ᱥᱴᱨᱚᱠ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ, ᱚᱱᱟᱛᱮ ᱟᱢ ᱫᱚ 'ᱥᱤᱫᱟᱹ ᱢᱮᱰᱤᱥᱤᱱ' ᱮᱛᱚᱦᱚᱵ ᱞᱟᱹᱠᱛᱤ ᱠᱟᱱ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱾

question: What is the meaning of the word 'nomadist'?
answer: On 26 January, he was followed by a herd of wild animals; after filling the watering hole, the animals turned to beat him to death.

question: ᱤᱧᱟᱹᱜ ᱴᱨᱮᱠᱤᱭᱳᱥᱴᱳᱢᱤ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜ ᱞᱟᱹᱠᱛᱤ ᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱥᱮ ?
answer: He was on a 'fibroscope' and had no symptoms. He had a decanulization (tube removal) on 3 March 2010. After discharge, he was on a 'tracheostomy' with drainage.

On 03/01 he presented respiratory discomfort, having sought care on 04/01, when antibiotic therapy was changed to intravenous; the family member does not know which medication, however, there was no indication for hospital admission. [person] persisted with respiratory discomfort, having been hospitalized in the early hours of the same day. Emergency care unit report of oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, progressively worsening. He was admitted to the emergency unit on 06/01 with severe pulmonary involvement on chest x-ray, and was continued on antibiotic therapy initiated in the emergency care unit, ceftriaxone daily on 05/01 and prophylactic dexamethasone and enoxaparin initiated. He was admitted to [organization] on 07/01, requiring orotracheal intubation and central venous catheterization. He presented septic shock on 14/01, and his antibiotic regimen was changed. He remained in bed at [organization]. He developed new septic shock on 24/01, and began using fluconazole for fungal coverage. He developed pneumomediastinum on 26/01 due to airway injury, and underwent conservative treatment. He underwent tracheostomy on 29/01. He presented reactive adrenal insufficiency and acneiform rash related to corticosteroid therapy, in addition to diarrhea treated empirically with the hypothesis of pseudomembranous colitis. Acinetobacter baumanii was isolated in the tracheal aspirate, but was not treated due to the lack of clinical repercussion. He presented progressive clinical improvement and was transferred to [organization], where he remained stable. He underwent fibroscopy and was evaluated by speech therapy on 02/03, with no residual airway injury identified and a soft diet was released. He was decannulated on 03/03, remaining eupneic and in condition to be discharged. Good general condition, alert, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile, Glasgow 15, oxygen saturation 94% in room air with capped tracheostomy, respiratory rate 28 inspirations per minute, muscle strength grade 4 in upper and lower limbs, regular heart rhythm in two beats, normal sound sounds without murmurs. Heart rate 76, vesicular breath sounds present, symmetrical, without adventitious sounds, without use of accessory muscles. Flaccid, flat abdomen, painless to palpation, without masses or visceromegaly. Extremities: palpable peripheral pulses, without edema, absence of swelling of the calves. Presence of pressure ulcer in the left lower limb, without signs of infection. Tracheostomy fibroscopy. I advise [person] on outpatient follow-up visits for: head and neck surgery on 03/15 speech therapy on 03/25 reassessment of diet physiatry to be scheduled I advise [person] on home care for tracheostomy orifice, diet, exercise and care. I prescribe symptomatic medications. Aminc, head and neck surgery, speech therapy, physiatry. Good general condition, slim, conscious and oriented, moving all 4 limbs actively with grade 4 muscle strength, still not able to walk alone. Tracheostomy orifice occluded with dressing and eating a soft diet. No pain complaints.
question: ᱟᱵᱚ ᱪᱮᱫ ᱮᱠᱞᱟ ᱵᱚᱱ ᱪᱟᱞᱟᱣ ᱫᱟᱲᱮᱭᱟᱜᱼᱟ ?
answer: You had a speech therapy checkup on February 2nd and 3rd, 2010, and you started eating soft food. You were given a discount, and you were eating soft food.

question: ᱠᱮᱴᱤᱱ, ᱤᱧᱟᱹᱜ ᱞᱩᱛᱩᱨ ᱦᱟᱹᱥᱩ ᱵᱮᱥ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱥᱮ ᱵᱟᱝ ?
answer: You are in 'good, normal' condition. Your pulse is normal, oxygen saturation is normal at 94%. Glasgow 15, bar. You can walk safely with fourth degree mobility in your hands and feet, but not independently.

question: ᱵᱟᱝᱠᱷᱟᱱ ᱟᱢ ᱪᱮᱫ ᱧᱮᱞ ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ ᱥᱮ ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ ᱮᱢ ᱠᱷᱚᱡ ᱠᱟᱱᱟ ?
answer: ᱟᱢ ᱫᱚ ᱟᱢᱨᱮᱱ ᱵᱚᱭᱦᱟ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱪᱤᱠᱤᱛᱥᱟ ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ ᱪᱟᱞᱟᱜ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜ ᱛᱟᱢᱟᱺ ᱐᱓/᱑᱕ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱦᱚᱭ ᱦᱤᱥᱤᱫ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱠᱷᱚᱛᱤ ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ ᱮᱠᱮᱱ ᱥᱟᱨᱡᱟᱨᱤ ᱟᱨ ᱐᱓/᱒᱕ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱜᱟᱞᱚᱪ ᱪᱤᱠᱤᱛᱥᱟ ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ... ᱟᱢ ᱫᱚ ᱢᱤᱫᱴᱟᱝ ᱚᱠᱛᱚ ᱥᱩᱪᱤ ᱵᱮᱱᱟᱣ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜ ᱛᱟᱢᱟ ᱯᱷᱤᱡᱤᱭᱳᱛᱷᱮᱨᱟᱯᱤ ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ ᱾

discharge_summary: 1. pneumonia, pulmonary metastasis? negative external rt pcr on 06/21 verified by surveillance on 06/23 2. syncope to be clarified neurocardiogenic? investigation suspended 3. consumptive syndrome due to duodenal papilla neoplasia. admission: 06/23/2020, discharge: 06/30/2020, stay: 07 d 05 h, location: ward, payer: sus. history of current illness admission: [person] referred from the emergency care unit, where he was hospitalized for 4 days. reports that 3 days ago he had a sudden episode of loss of consciousness, not preceded by prodromes, with follow-up appointment after a few seconds. level of consciousness without dysfunctions afterwards, without release of sphincters. reports only significant asthenia and fatigue associated. had 2 of these episodes on this day. had already had another similar syncope 20 days ago. He had several episodes of vomiting, which started 5 days ago and improved 2 days ago. His family called [organization] due to his condition. During the evaluation by the transport team, [person] reported an episode of fever (38.3 °C) and dry cough since 06/10. During hospitalization at [organization], he was given antibiotic therapy and referred [person] to our services. His syncope did not recur. He reported diarrhea for 15 days and improvement for 3 days, which is why his chemotherapy cycle was suspended. Upon admission, [person] was hemodynamically stable, breathing with a mask with a reservoir at 10 L/min, without respiratory distress, and denying any complaints at the moment. He is afebrile. Edema of the lower limbs, crackles, and reduced vesicular breath sounds on the left. [person] was pale and emaciated. No relevant results. Pleural fluid puncture and chest drain. Pneumonia, no pending tests. Antibiotic therapy: cefepime and clarithromycin. [person] evolves into death.
question: ᱤᱧ ᱪᱮᱫ ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞ ᱤᱫᱤ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜ ᱛᱤᱧᱟ ?
answer: ᱟᱢ ᱫᱚ 'ᱮᱢᱟᱨᱡᱮᱱᱥᱤ ᱠᱮᱭᱟᱨ ᱤᱭᱩᱱᱤᱴ' ᱨᱮᱢ ᱠᱩᱞ ᱞᱮᱫ ᱠᱚᱣᱟ ᱾ ᱟᱢ ᱫᱚ ᱓ ᱢᱟᱦᱟ ᱢᱟᱲᱟᱝ 'ᱟᱪᱠᱟ ᱧᱩᱨᱩᱜ ᱠᱟᱱ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ' ᱟᱨ ᱟᱢ ᱫᱚ ᱟᱹᱰᱤ ᱞᱚᱞᱚ ᱟᱨ ᱦᱟᱥᱩ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱾ ᱟᱢ ᱫᱚ ᱟᱹᱰᱤ ᱞᱚᱞᱚ (᱓᱘ᱹ᱓ ᱰᱤᱜᱽᱨᱤ ᱥᱮᱞᱥᱤᱭᱟᱥ) ᱟᱨ ᱨᱚᱦᱚᱲ ᱠᱷᱩᱜ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱾

question: ᱟᱢ ᱪᱮᱫ 'ᱠᱳᱱᱤᱜ ᱥᱤᱱᱰᱨᱳᱢ' ᱵᱟᱨᱮᱛᱮᱢ ᱞᱟᱹᱭ ᱮᱫᱟ ?
answer: ᱱᱟᱯᱟᱭ ᱛᱤᱨᱞᱟᱹ ᱠᱚᱣᱟᱜ ᱵᱚᱨᱱᱚᱱ ᱮᱢ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ "ᱜᱩᱞᱟᱹᱪ ᱨᱚᱝ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ" ᱟᱨ "ᱩᱵᱽ ᱥᱟᱶ, ᱦᱩᱭ ᱫᱟᱲᱮᱭᱟᱜᱼᱟ ᱵᱟᱨ ᱥᱮᱫ ᱯᱮᱯᱤᱞᱮᱥᱤᱭᱟᱥ ᱱᱤᱣᱳᱯᱞᱟᱡᱚᱢ (ᱠᱮᱱᱥᱟᱨ)" ᱾

During hospitalization at [organization], he was given antibiotic therapy and referred [person] to our services. His syncope did not recur. He reported diarrhea for 15 days and improvement for 3 days, which is why his chemotherapy cycle was suspended. Upon admission, [person] was hemodynamically stable, breathing with a mask with a reservoir at 10 L/min, without respiratory distress, and denying any complaints at the moment. He is afebrile. Edema of the lower limbs, crackles, and reduced vesicular breath sounds on the left. [person] was pale and emaciated. No relevant results. Pleural fluid puncture and chest drain. Pneumonia, no pending tests. Antibiotic therapy: cefepime and clarithromycin. [person] evolves into death.

question: ᱤᱧ ᱪᱮᱫ ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞᱤᱧ ᱪᱟᱞᱟᱜ ᱠᱟᱱᱟ ?
answer: ᱟᱢ ᱟᱹᱰᱤ ᱡᱳᱨ ᱥᱟᱸᱦᱮᱫ ᱦᱟᱛᱟᱣ ᱨᱮᱢ ᱟᱱᱟᱴ ᱮᱫ ᱠᱟᱱ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱫ ᱾ ᱒᱘ ᱢᱮ ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱪᱤᱱᱦᱟᱹ ᱠᱚ "ᱥᱚᱴᱠᱟᱴᱚᱠ" ᱦᱟᱞᱚᱛ ᱨᱮ ᱵᱟᱹᱲᱤᱡ ᱮᱱᱟ, ᱟᱨ ᱒᱙ ᱢᱮ ᱟᱢᱟᱜ "ᱟᱨᱴᱤᱼᱯᱤᱥᱤᱟᱨ" (ᱠᱳᱵᱷᱤᱰ ᱵᱤᱰᱟᱹᱣ) ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱚᱨᱡᱚ ᱯᱚᱡᱤᱴᱤᱵᱷ ᱦᱮᱡ ᱮᱱᱟ ᱾

question: ᱪᱮᱫᱟᱜ ᱟᱭᱳ ᱫᱚ ᱵᱷᱮᱱᱴᱤᱞᱮᱴᱚᱨ ᱨᱮ ᱫᱚᱦᱚ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ?
answer: On 29 ᱢᱮ, ᱟᱢ ᱡᱚᱠᱷᱚᱱ ᱠᱳᱵᱷᱤᱰᱼ᱑᱙ ᱵᱤᱰᱟᱹᱣ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱚᱨᱡᱚ ᱯᱚᱡᱤᱴᱤᱵᱷ ᱦᱮᱡ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ, ᱟᱢ ᱫᱚ 'ᱮᱭᱟᱨᱳᱭᱮ ᱤᱱᱴᱤᱭᱩᱵᱮᱥᱚᱱ ᱮᱱᱰ ᱢᱮᱠᱟᱱᱤᱠᱮᱞ ᱵᱷᱮᱱᱴᱤᱞᱮᱥᱚᱱ' ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞ ᱨᱮᱢ ᱵᱷᱚᱨᱛᱤ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱟᱨ ᱟᱢᱟᱜ 'ᱥᱟᱥ ᱦᱟᱛᱟᱣ ᱨᱮ ᱟᱱᱟᱴ' ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾

question: ᱪᱮᱫ ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱠᱳᱵᱷᱤᱰᱼ᱑᱙ ᱵᱮᱜᱚᱨ ᱮᱴᱟᱜ ᱡᱟᱦᱟᱱ ᱟᱡᱟᱨ ᱢᱮᱱᱟᱜᱼᱟ ?
answer: ᱥᱟᱸᱦᱮᱫ ᱦᱚᱨ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱯᱟᱸᱡᱟ ᱧᱟᱢ ᱠᱚ ᱢᱩᱫᱽᱨᱮ ᱢᱮᱱᱟᱜᱼᱟ 'ᱤᱥᱴ ᱥᱚᱝᱠᱨᱚᱢᱚᱱ' (ᱠᱮᱱᱰᱤᱰᱟ ᱟᱞᱵᱤᱠᱟᱱᱥ), 'ᱡᱟᱱᱛᱨᱤᱠ ᱵᱷᱮᱱᱴᱤᱞᱮᱥᱚᱱᱼ ᱯᱨᱚᱨᱳᱪᱤᱛ ᱱᱤᱭᱩᱢᱳᱱᱤᱭᱟ', ᱦᱤᱫᱤᱪ ᱟᱱᱟᱜ 'ᱠᱮᱛᱷᱮᱴᱟᱨᱼ ᱥᱟᱹᱜᱟᱹᱭᱟᱱ ᱢᱟᱭᱟᱢ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱥᱚᱝᱠᱨᱚᱢᱚᱱ' ᱟᱨ 'ᱥᱩᱰᱳᱢᱳᱱᱟᱥ ᱮᱨᱩᱜᱤᱱᱳᱥᱟ' ᱾

question: ᱪᱮᱫᱟᱜ ᱟᱵᱚᱣᱟᱜ ᱡᱚᱢᱟᱜ ᱥᱚᱨᱚᱵᱚᱨᱟᱦᱚ ᱠᱚᱢᱚᱜ ᱠᱟᱱᱟ ?
answer: ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱠᱤᱰᱱᱤ ᱫᱚ ᱑᱘ ᱡᱩᱱ ᱠᱷᱚᱱ ᱠᱟᱹᱢᱤ ᱵᱟᱹᱱᱩᱜ ᱠᱟᱱᱟ (ᱥᱴᱮᱡ ᱓) ᱾ ᱒᱐ ᱡᱩᱱ ᱨᱮ ᱱᱚᱣᱟ ᱫᱚᱲᱦᱟ ᱵᱮᱥᱚᱜ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱟᱨ ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱦᱤᱢᱳᱰᱟᱭᱞᱤᱥᱤᱥ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱞᱟᱹᱠᱛᱤ ᱢᱮᱱᱟᱜᱼᱟ ᱾

question: ᱪᱮᱫᱟᱜ ᱵᱟᱝ ᱟᱵᱚ ᱚᱱᱟ ᱨᱟᱱ (ᱱᱟᱠᱥᱳᱯᱮᱦᱮᱨᱤᱱ) ᱵᱚᱱ ᱟᱴᱚᱠ ᱮᱫᱟ ᱡᱟᱦᱟᱸ ᱫᱚ ᱢᱟᱭᱟᱢ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱦᱟᱹᱱ ᱮ ᱠᱚᱨᱟᱣᱟ ?
answer: ᱒᱐ ᱡᱩᱱ ᱩᱱᱤ ᱫᱚ ᱠᱤᱰᱱᱤ ᱵᱮᱨᱛᱷᱚ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱵᱤᱰᱟᱹᱣ ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞ ᱨᱮ ᱵᱷᱚᱨᱛᱤ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱟᱨ ᱑᱔ ᱡᱩᱱ ᱛᱷᱨᱳᱢᱵᱳᱥᱮᱰ ᱮᱢᱵᱳᱞᱤᱡᱚᱢ ᱧᱮᱞ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ, ᱫᱷᱚᱢᱚᱱᱤ ᱨᱮ ᱢᱤᱫᱴᱟᱝ ᱡᱚᱢᱟᱴ ᱡᱟᱦᱟᱸ ᱫᱚ ᱤᱱᱯᱷᱟᱨᱠᱥᱚᱱ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱚᱡᱮ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸ ᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱾

question: ᱪᱮᱫ ᱚᱨᱡᱚ ᱧᱟᱢ ᱮᱱᱟ ?
answer: ᱥᱩᱱᱫᱚᱨ ᱯᱤᱪᱟᱭ ᱞᱟᱹᱭ ᱞᱮᱫᱟᱭ, "ᱥᱠᱨᱤᱯᱴ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱦᱤᱲᱤᱡ ᱠᱷᱟᱹᱛᱤᱨ ᱥᱳ ᱫᱚ ᱵᱟᱹᱛᱤᱞ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾"

discharge_summary: 1. coronavirus infection onset of symptoms 02/17 orotracheal intubation 02/24 extubation 03/08 2. septic shock from pulmonary focus requiring vasoactive drug resolved: antibiotic therapy: ceftriaxone 02/23 03/02 clarithromycin 04/24 03/02 corticosteroid therapy: 02/24 03/09 3. critically ill polyneuropathy grade 2 strength upper limbs and lower limbs 4. pressure injury left lower limb grade i 5. your appointment scheduled with gynecology. on 03/24 for investigation. admission: 02/24/2020, discharge: 03/19/2020, stay: 22 d 21 h, location: ward, payer: sus. current: [person] with severe acute respiratory syndrome due to coronavirus, onset of symptoms on 02/17, requiring orotracheal intubation due to respiratory failure on 02/24, due to the possibility of associated bacterial pneumonia, antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and clarithromycin was performed. [person] presented satisfactory clinical evolution, and extubation was performed on 03/08, without complications. Gradual weaning of oxygen therapy was performed, and oxygen was withdrawn on 03/17, at the time comfortable in room air. Due to prolonged use of neuromuscular blocker to manage mechanical ventilation, [person] developed critically ill polyneuropathy, currently with grade II motor strength in the upper and lower limbs. He also has a pressure injury in the left lower limb, which is improving, with no signs of infection. Insulin therapy was started to manage hyperglycemia, with weaning after optimization of oral metformin. It is worth mentioning that during hospitalization [person] presented abnormal vaginal bleeding, and an appointment with gynecology was scheduled for 03/24 for investigation. Good general condition, hydrated, normal color, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile; respiratory auscultation: vesicular breath sounds with crackles on a residual basis, without respiratory distress; cardiac auscultation: regular heart rhythm in two beats; normal sound sounds without murmurs; abdomen: innocent; extremities without edema, free calves, capillary refill time less than 3 s, ulcer on the left lower limb, grade I. therapeutic plan: I speak with [person] about the importance of performing pulmonary and motor physiotherapy to manage polyneuropathy in critically ill patients. He states that he will pay for home physiotherapy. He is referred to a basic health unit: management of hypertension and diabetes. Dressing of ulcer in the left lower limb region. I prescribe a dressing with AGE. Guidance from the nutrition team regarding the home diet. I follow-up appointment to the GEAD outpatient clinic on 04/26 for clinical reassessment. I follow-up appointment to the speech therapy outpatient clinic on 05/05. I schedule a pelvic ultrasound for 03/22 and a surgical gynecology outpatient clinic for 03/24. I investigate uterine bleeding. against reference [organization]. Good general condition, maintaining polyneuropathy in critically ill patients, with improvement in motor strength grade II.
question: ᱤᱧ ᱪᱮᱫ ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞᱤᱧ ᱪᱟᱞᱟᱜ ᱠᱟᱱᱟ ?
answer: ᱩᱱᱤ ᱒᱐᱒᱐ ᱥᱟᱞ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱒᱔ ᱯᱷᱮᱵᱨᱩᱣᱟᱨᱤ ᱦᱤᱞᱳᱜ ᱠᱚᱨᱳᱱᱟ ᱵᱷᱟᱭᱨᱟᱥ ᱠᱷᱟᱹᱛᱤᱨ ᱛᱮ ᱟᱹᱰᱤ ᱡᱳᱨ ᱥᱟᱸᱦᱮᱫ ᱦᱟᱛᱟᱣ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱥᱤᱱᱰᱨᱳᱢ ᱛᱮ ᱡᱟᱲᱩᱨ ᱛᱮ ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞ ᱨᱮ ᱵᱷᱚᱨᱛᱤ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱟᱨ ᱩᱱᱤ ᱤᱱᱴᱤᱭᱩᱵᱮᱴ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾

question: Is there a need for antibiotics like Enamox?
answer: The recommended antibiotic treatment for bacterial pneumonia is ceftriaxone and clarithromycin.

question: ᱪᱮᱫᱟᱜ ᱤᱧᱟᱹᱜ ᱛᱤ ᱟᱨ ᱡᱟᱸᱜᱟ ᱱᱩᱱᱟᱹᱜ ᱞᱤᱪᱟᱹᱲ ᱜᱮᱭᱟ ?
answer: After long term use of the neurohormonal depressants, he went into a deeply blotted coma from which he was not recovered.

question: ᱪᱮᱫ ᱠᱷᱟᱹᱛᱤᱨ ᱟᱵᱚᱣᱟᱜ 'ᱟᱥᱟᱫᱷᱟᱨᱚᱱ ᱢᱟᱭᱟᱢ' ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱦᱟᱹᱱ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ ?
answer: ᱵᱤᱥᱮᱥ ᱠᱟᱭᱛᱮ, "[ᱡᱚᱨᱟᱭᱩ] ᱵᱮᱼᱥᱟᱵᱷᱟᱵᱤᱠ ᱞᱮᱠᱟᱛᱮ ᱯᱟᱥᱱᱟᱣ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾ ᱟᱢ ᱡᱚᱨᱟᱭᱩ ᱟᱡᱟᱨ ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ ᱵᱷᱚᱨᱛᱤ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾ [ᱵᱤᱰᱟᱹᱣ] ᱒᱔ ᱢᱟᱨᱪ ᱒᱐᱒᱑ ᱨᱮ ᱛᱟᱹᱞᱤᱠᱟ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾" ᱟᱨ "ᱡᱚᱨᱟᱭᱩ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱦᱟᱢᱟᱞ ᱦᱚᱲᱢᱚ ᱵᱤᱰᱟᱹᱣ ᱒᱒ ᱢᱟᱨᱪ ᱒᱐᱒᱑ ᱨᱮ ᱯᱮᱞᱵᱷᱤᱠ ᱟᱞᱴᱨᱟᱥᱟᱣᱩᱱᱰ ᱫᱟᱨᱟᱭᱛᱮ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜᱼᱟ ᱾

question: ᱤᱧᱟᱹᱜ ᱡᱟᱦᱟᱱ ᱮᱢᱹᱮ ᱯᱷᱚᱞᱳᱼᱟᱯ ᱟᱯᱚᱭᱤᱱᱴᱢᱮᱱᱴ ᱢᱮᱱᱟᱜᱼᱟ ᱥᱮ?
answer: ᱟᱢ 'ᱟᱹᱰᱤ ᱡᱟᱹᱥᱛᱤ ᱢᱟᱭᱟᱢ ᱩᱰᱩᱠ ᱟᱨ ᱩᱞᱴᱟᱹ ᱵᱩᱞᱩᱝ' ᱠᱷᱟᱹᱛᱤᱨ 'ᱢᱩᱲᱩᱫ ᱥᱟᱶᱟᱨ ᱜᱟᱫᱮᱞ' ᱨᱮᱢ ᱵᱚᱞᱚ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ, ᱟᱨ ᱟᱢ ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱞᱩᱜᱽᱲᱤ ᱵᱚᱫᱚᱞ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜ ᱛᱟᱢᱟ ᱾ ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱨᱚᱲ ᱛᱷᱮᱨᱟᱯᱤ ᱯᱷᱤ ᱫᱚ ᱒᱖/᱐᱔, ᱟᱣᱩᱴᱯᱮᱥᱮᱱᱴ ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞ ᱐᱕/᱐᱕, ᱯᱮᱞᱵᱷᱤᱠ ᱟᱞᱴᱨᱟᱥᱟᱣᱩᱱᱰ ᱒᱒/᱐᱓, ᱟᱨ ᱜᱟᱭᱱᱮᱠᱳᱞᱚᱡᱤᱥᱴ ᱟᱣᱩᱴᱯᱮᱥᱮᱱᱴ ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞ ᱾

question: In ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞ, ᱪᱮᱫ ᱟᱢ ᱠᱳᱵᱷᱤᱰ ᱵᱮᱜᱚᱨ ᱮᱴᱟᱜ ᱡᱟᱦᱟᱱ ᱟᱡᱟᱨ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸ ᱠᱟᱱᱟ ?
answer: ᱮᱥᱮᱯᱴᱤᱠ ᱢᱮᱱᱤᱱᱡᱟᱭᱴᱤᱥ (ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞ ᱨᱮ ᱵᱷᱚᱨᱛᱤ ᱠᱷᱚᱱ ᱦᱟᱛᱟᱣ) ᱢᱩᱫᱨᱮ ᱢᱮᱱᱟᱜᱼᱟ 'ᱮᱥᱮᱯᱴᱤᱠ ᱱᱤᱭᱩᱢᱳᱱᱤᱭᱟ', 'ᱵᱤᱞᱚᱢ ᱟᱱ ᱮᱥᱯᱤᱨᱮᱥᱚᱱᱼᱥᱚᱢᱵᱚᱱᱫᱷᱤᱛ ᱱᱤᱭᱩᱢᱳᱱᱤᱭᱟ' (ᱠᱞᱟᱵᱷᱮᱞᱟ ᱱᱤᱭᱩᱢᱳᱱᱤᱭᱟ) ᱟᱨ 'ᱠᱮᱛᱷᱮᱴᱟᱨᱼᱥᱚᱢᱵᱚᱱᱫᱷᱤᱛ ᱢᱟᱭᱟᱢ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱡᱚᱨᱚᱜᱮᱢ' (ᱥᱴᱮᱯᱷᱤᱞᱳᱠᱚᱠᱟᱥ ᱚᱨᱤᱭᱟᱥ) ᱾

question: ᱪᱮᱫ, ᱤᱧ ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞᱤᱧ ᱪᱟᱞᱟᱣ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ?
answer: ᱩᱱᱤ ᱫᱚ 'ᱥᱚᱫᱚᱢ' ᱨᱮᱭ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ, 'ᱯᱮᱨᱮᱡ', 'ᱵᱮᱦᱳᱥ' ᱟᱨ 'ᱟᱡᱟᱨ' ᱛᱮᱭ ᱡᱟᱲᱟᱣ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾ ᱥᱟᱜᱟᱲᱚᱢ ᱫᱚᱞ ᱩᱱᱤᱭ ᱵᱟᱧᱪᱟᱣ ᱞᱮᱫᱮᱭᱟ ᱪᱮᱫᱟᱜ ᱥᱮ ᱩᱱᱤᱭᱟᱜ ᱵᱞᱟᱰ ᱯᱨᱮᱥᱟᱨ ᱫᱚ ᱜᱞᱟᱥᱜᱳ ᱖ ᱠᱷᱚᱱ ᱖᱐x᱐᱐ mmHg ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ, ᱟᱨ ᱩᱱᱤᱭᱟᱜ ᱛᱤ ᱟᱨ ᱡᱟᱸᱜᱟ ᱫᱚ ᱵᱮᱸᱜᱮᱫ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾

question: ᱵᱮᱲᱛᱤ ᱦᱟᱥᱩ ᱞᱮᱱᱠᱷᱟᱱ ᱟᱢ ᱢᱤᱫ ᱠᱚᱲᱟ ᱰᱟᱠᱛᱟᱨ ᱨᱮᱱᱟᱜ ᱞᱟᱹᱠᱛᱤ ᱢᱮᱱᱟᱜᱼᱟ ᱪᱮᱫ ?
answer: ᱫᱚᱥᱟᱨ ᱜᱷᱟᱹᱞᱤᱡ ᱫᱚ ᱤᱱᱴᱩᱵᱮᱴ ᱠᱟᱛᱮ ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞ ᱨᱮ ᱵᱷᱚᱨᱛᱤ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱟᱨ ᱩᱱᱤ ᱫᱚ "ᱦᱤᱸᱥᱠᱟᱹᱨᱤ ᱦᱚᱭ ᱰᱟᱦᱟᱨ ᱨᱮ ᱵᱟᱫᱷᱟ" ᱟᱨ "ᱦᱤᱸᱥᱠᱟᱹᱨᱤ ᱥᱟᱥᱚᱱ ᱵᱤᱨᱛᱷᱟ" ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ ᱛᱮ ᱾

question: ᱥᱮᱯᱴᱤᱠ ᱪᱮᱫᱟᱜ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜᱼᱟ ?
answer: He was diagnosed with " septic shock abdominal focus " and " septic shock hematosis ". His symptoms included "general weakness, diarrhea, and low creatinine" and "hemodynamic instability" (red streaks), so he had to take "norepinephrine" (a drug that increases redness).

question: ᱤᱧᱨᱮᱱ ᱵᱚᱭᱦᱟ ᱪᱮᱫ ᱨᱩᱣᱟᱹ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ ?
answer: He was correctly diagnosed with 'Clubbill pneumonia' and 'Culture 03/22'. This resulted in 'Septic shock haemorrhage' and 'haematodynamic instability'.

question: ᱦᱤᱫᱫᱷᱚᱯᱚᱱᱰᱚ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱠᱟᱹᱢᱤ (ᱤᱠᱳᱠᱟᱨᱰᱤᱭᱳᱜᱨᱟᱢ) ᱪᱮᱫ ᱞᱮᱠᱟᱛᱮ ᱩᱫᱩᱜ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜᱼᱟ?
answer: ᱴᱨᱟᱱᱥᱤᱥᱳᱯᱷᱟᱡᱤᱭᱟᱞ ᱤᱠᱳᱠᱟᱨᱰᱤᱭᱳᱜᱨᱟᱢ (ᱴᱤᱹᱥᱤᱹᱤ) "ᱧᱩᱢ ᱞᱮᱠᱟᱛᱮ ᱠᱚᱢ ᱥᱤᱥᱴᱳᱞᱤᱠ ᱤᱠᱳᱠᱟᱨᱰᱤᱭᱳᱜᱨᱟᱢ ᱦᱤᱞᱳᱜ ᱴᱷᱟᱶ", "ᱟᱝᱥᱤᱠ ᱥᱮᱠᱢᱮᱱᱴᱟᱞ ᱰᱚᱯᱞᱟᱨ ᱵᱷᱮᱞᱳᱥᱤᱴᱤ" ᱟᱨ "ᱦᱟᱞᱠᱟ ᱢᱤᱴᱨᱟᱞ ᱵᱷᱟᱞᱵᱷ ᱟᱱᱟᱯᱚᱨᱤᱢᱤᱛᱛᱚ" ᱩᱪᱷᱟᱹᱱ ᱟᱠᱟᱫᱟᱭ ᱾

question: ᱳᱭᱮ, ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱞᱩᱛᱩᱨ ᱨᱮ ᱪᱮᱫ ᱦᱮᱡ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ, ᱵᱚᱭᱦᱟ ?
answer: ᱟᱢ 'ᱟᱥᱟᱫᱷᱟᱨᱚᱱ ᱦᱤᱫᱤᱫ ᱫᱷᱚᱠᱚᱱ' ᱯᱟᱲᱦᱟᱣ ᱨᱮᱢ ᱥᱮᱞᱮᱫ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾ 'ᱤᱞᱮᱠᱴᱨᱳᱠᱟᱨᱰᱤᱭᱳᱜᱨᱟᱢ ᱮᱱᱴᱨᱤ ᱐᱓/᱑᱕' ᱫᱚ ᱡᱟᱦᱟᱱ 'ᱮᱴᱨᱤᱭᱟᱞ ᱯᱷᱟᱭᱵᱨᱤᱞᱮᱥᱚᱱ' ᱵᱟᱭ ᱯᱟᱸᱡᱟ ᱧᱟᱢ ᱟᱠᱟᱫᱟ, ᱡᱟᱦᱟᱸ ᱫᱚ ᱟᱢᱨᱮᱱ ᱜᱷᱟᱨᱚᱸᱡᱽ ᱨᱮᱱ ᱦᱚᱲᱠᱚ ᱯᱟᱸᱡᱟ ᱧᱟᱢ ᱞᱮᱫᱟ ᱟᱨ 'ᱢᱟᱲᱟᱝ ᱠᱷᱚᱱ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸ ᱠᱟᱱ ᱦᱟᱞᱚᱛ' ᱠᱚ ᱴᱷᱟᱹᱣᱠᱟᱹ ᱞᱮᱫᱟ ᱾

answer: A doctor was called, and he found the patient's 'pulse rate' 0 beats per minute, no electrical activity was detected on the monitor. Physical examination showed 'no central blockage'... no reflective surface, no reflective cornea, and the eye result was positive.

discharge_summary: 1. pneumonia, pulmonary metastasis? negative external rt pcr on 06/21 verified by surveillance on 06/23 2. syncope to be clarified neurocardiogenic? investigation suspended 3. consumptive syndrome due to duodenal papilla neoplasia. admission: 06/23/2020, discharge: 06/30/2020, stay: 07 d 05 h, location: ward, payer: sus. history of current illness admission: [person] referred from the emergency care unit, where he was hospitalized for 4 days. reports that 3 days ago he had a sudden episode of loss of consciousness, not preceded by prodromes, with follow-up appointment after a few seconds. level of consciousness without dysfunctions afterwards, without release of sphincters. reports only significant asthenia and fatigue associated. had 2 of these episodes on this day. had already had another similar syncope 20 days ago. He had several episodes of vomiting, which started 5 days ago and improved 2 days ago. His family called [organization] due to his condition. During the evaluation by the transport team, [person] reported an episode of fever (38.3 °C) and dry cough since 06/10. During hospitalization at [organization], he was given antibiotic therapy and referred [person] to our services. His syncope did not recur. He reported diarrhea for 15 days and improvement for 3 days, which is why his chemotherapy cycle was suspended. Upon admission, [person] was hemodynamically stable, breathing with a mask with a reservoir at 10 L/min, without respiratory distress, and denying any complaints at the moment. He is afebrile. Edema of the lower limbs, crackles, and reduced vesicular breath sounds on the left. [person] was pale and emaciated. No relevant results. Pleural fluid puncture and chest drain. Pneumonia, no pending tests. Antibiotic therapy: cefepime and clarithromycin. [person] evolves into death.

discharge_summary: admission: 23/02/2020, discharge: 09/03/2020, stay: 14 d, location: ward, payer: sus. [person], 65 years old, born and raised in [address], widower. problem: asthenia, worsening of basal dyspnea, drowsiness, desaturation, bladder indwelling urinary catheter with pyuria, hypotension and worsening of perfusion diagnostic hypotheses: 1. mixed shock: septic of urinary focus, weaning from norepinephrine on 25/02, cardiogenic, heart failure, due to decompensated alcoholic cardiomyopathy profile, weaning from dobutamine on 03/03 started tridil 26/02 and oral vasodilators on 27/02/2020. 2. acute kidney injury kdigo 3 creatinine: 6.57 urea: 348: acute ischemic tubular necrosis secondary to infection, SCR type 1 on renal replacement therapy since 02/23/2020. cultures: blood culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae in 2 samples at 22 and 42 h. urine culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae. history: systemic arterial hypertension, hypothyroidism? chronic liver disease, active significant alcoholism, active smoking 110 pack-years, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, presumed pulmonology evaluation on 08/18. Evolution: despite the culture showing Klebsiella pneumoniae carbapenemase, [person] showed a good clinical response to meropenem, thus concluding the use of meropenem 1000 mg 1x/day 500 mg post renal replacement therapy for 14 days dated 02/23/2020. He evolved with improvement in infectious parameters, afebrile, with no genitourinary or cardiorespiratory complaints. Latest laboratory tests: Hb: 12.4 ht: 37 platelets: 123 gb: 7.5 without deviation to the left. Undergoing follow-up with nephrology, daily hemodialysis was performed. Schedule: with completion of antibiotic therapy and maintenance of improvement in clinical parameters, discharged from [organization] on 03/09/2020. Scheduled by nephrology for follow-up on acute dialysis on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, in the first shift.

question: ᱤᱧᱟᱹᱜ ᱠᱨᱤᱭᱮᱴᱤᱱᱤᱱ ᱵᱮᱼᱥᱟᱵᱷᱟᱵᱤᱠ, ᱤᱧᱟᱹᱜ ᱪᱮᱫ ᱰᱟᱭᱟᱞᱤᱥᱤᱥ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜ ᱞᱟᱹᱠᱛᱤ ?
answer: ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱜᱩᱨᱩᱫᱷᱟᱨᱟ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱱᱟᱡᱩᱠ ᱢᱩᱪᱟᱹᱫ ᱚᱨᱡᱚ ᱫᱚ ᱓' (ᱠᱨᱤᱭᱟᱴᱤᱱᱟᱭᱤᱱᱺ ᱖.᱕᱗) ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ, ᱡᱟᱦᱟᱸ ᱫᱚ ᱢᱤᱫᱴᱟᱝ 'ᱤᱱᱯᱷᱮᱠᱥᱚᱱ' ᱠᱷᱟᱹᱛᱤᱨ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱾ ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱜᱩᱨᱩᱫᱷᱟᱨᱟ ᱴᱨᱟᱱᱥᱯᱞᱟᱱᱴ (ᱰᱟᱭᱞᱤᱥᱤᱥ) ᱫᱚ ᱒/᱒᱓/᱒᱐᱒᱐ ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ ᱛᱮ ᱛᱷᱤᱨ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱾

discharge_summary: admission: 23/02/2020, discharge: 09/03/2020, stay: 14 d, location: ward, payer: sus. [person], 65 years old, born and raised in [address], widower. problem: asthenia, worsening of basal dyspnea, drowsiness, desaturation, bladder indwelling urinary catheter with pyuria, hypotension and worsening of perfusion diagnostic hypotheses: 1. mixed shock: septic of urinary focus, weaning from norepinephrine on 25/02, cardiogenic, heart failure, due to decompensated alcoholic cardiomyopathy profile, weaning from dobutamine on 03/03 started tridil 26/02 and oral vasodilators on 27/02/2020. 2. acute kidney injury kdigo 3 creatinine: 6.57 urea: 348: acute ischemic tubular necrosis secondary to infection, SCR type 1 on renal replacement therapy since 02/23/2020. cultures: blood culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae in 2 samples at 22 and 42 h. urine culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae. history: systemic arterial hypertension, hypothyroidism? chronic liver disease, active significant alcoholism, active smoking 110 pack-years, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, presumed pulmonology evaluation on 08/18. Evolution: despite the culture showing Klebsiella pneumoniae carbapenemase, [person] showed a good clinical response to meropenem, thus concluding the use of meropenem 1000 mg 1x/day 500 mg post renal replacement therapy for 14 days dated 02/23/2020. He evolved with improvement in infectious parameters, afebrile, with no genitourinary or cardiorespiratory complaints. Latest laboratory tests: Hb: 12.4 ht: 37 platelets: 123 gb: 7.5 without deviation to the left. Undergoing follow-up with nephrology, daily hemodialysis was performed. Schedule: with completion of antibiotic therapy and maintenance of improvement in clinical parameters, discharged from [organization] on 03/09/2020. Scheduled by nephrology for follow-up on acute dialysis on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, in the first shift.
question: ᱤᱧᱟᱹᱜ ᱨᱤᱯᱳᱨᱴ ᱞᱮᱠᱟᱛᱮ ᱤᱧ ᱴᱷᱮᱱ ᱢᱤᱫᱴᱟᱝ 'ᱨᱳᱫᱷᱚᱠ' ᱵᱮᱜᱽ ᱢᱮᱱᱟᱜᱼᱟ ᱾ ᱤᱧ ᱢᱚᱱᱮᱭᱮᱫᱟ ᱤᱧᱟᱹᱜ ᱮᱱᱴᱤᱵᱟᱭᱳᱴᱤᱠ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱞᱟᱹᱠᱛᱤ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜᱼᱟ ᱾ (ᱢᱚᱨᱯᱷᱤᱱ)
answer: ᱥᱚᱨᱚᱥᱚᱛᱤ ᱞᱟᱹᱭ ᱟᱠᱟᱫᱟᱭ, "ᱡᱚᱠᱷᱚᱱ ᱥᱚᱝᱥᱠᱨᱤᱛ ᱫᱚ 'ᱢᱤᱫ ᱜᱟᱫᱮᱞ ᱦᱚᱲ ᱠᱚᱣᱟᱜ ᱜᱚᱱᱚᱝ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱯᱩᱨᱟᱹᱣ' ᱞᱮᱠᱟᱛᱮ ᱞᱟᱹᱭ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ, ᱩᱱᱫᱚ ᱱᱚᱣᱟ ᱯᱟᱹᱱᱟᱹᱨᱥᱤ ᱫᱚ 'ᱢᱤᱫ ᱨᱤᱥᱤ ᱟᱜ ᱵᱮᱣᱦᱟᱨ' ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱨᱩᱯ ᱦᱟᱛᱟᱣ ᱞᱮᱫᱟᱭ ᱾"

discharge_summary: id: [person], 49 years old, from [address], born in {city}. admission 17/11/2020 1. severe alcoholic hepatitis with child b7 meld encephalopathy on the 9th abdominal ultrasound 11/17 hepatomegaly and diffuse increased liver echogenicity, suggestive of fatty disease. gallstones. mild splenomegaly. last alcoholic libation in mid-november 2. fever probable urinary focus urine culture 12/30/2020 multisensitive escherichia coli ceftriaxone in: 12/30/2020 complications resolved with hospitalization:. chronic diarrhea associated with alcohol. respiratory failure nosocomial pneumonia 12/07: fever, tachypnea, requiring oxygen chest tomography 12/06/2020: pulmonary opacities with an organizing pneumonia pattern that may correspond to an inflammatory or infectious process, which may present with viral pneumonia, involving 25-30% of the parenchyma. bilateral pleural effusion. severe coronary atheromatosis rapid coronavirus test 12/08/2020 negative coronavirus PCR 12/07/2020: inconclusive, orotracheal intubation for acute respiratory failure on 12/13 extubation on 12/23 performed 7 days of meropenem termination 12/15, personal history: mood disorder? systemic arterial hypertension, obesity, diabetes mellitus? dyslipidemia, epilepsy? Habits: Active alcoholism 67 cans of beer per day and half a liter of distilled spirits on weekends for 25 years, active tobacco smoking 12.5 pack-years Other relevant tests Abdominal ultrasound 09/04 External liver with blunt edges, gallbladder without alterations Diffuse infiltration of the hepatic parenchyma, storage disease Chronic liver disease and hepatomegaly Portal hypertension Liposubstituted pancreas, enlarged lymph nodes Sparse colonic diverticula, no inflammatory signs Gastric biopsy 11/19: fragments of gastric mucosa Antral and body patterns, fundus with mild and inactive chronic gastritis. Helicobacter pylori research was negative in this material Absence of signs of intestinal metaplasia, epithelial dysplasia and malignancy. medications for continuous use at home: losartan 50 mg 100 sertraline 100 mg 100 simvastatin 20 mg 001 clonazepam 5 mg 001 valproic acid does not know the dose phenobarbital 1 tablet at night fenofibrate complex b current previous antibiotic therapy piperacillin tazobactam 11/29 12/08 amoxicillin clavulanate 11/19 11/22 empirical to combat helicobacter pylori metronidazole 11/19 11/25 nitazoxanide 11/18 11/20 meropenem in: 12/08 12/15 ceftriaxone in 12/30. admission: 11/17/2020, discharge: 01/05/2021, stay: 01 m 18 d 12 h, location: ward, payer: sus. good general condition, pale 1 / 4, hydrated, anicteric, acyanotic, afebrile to the touch and eupneic in room air respiratory auscultation vesicular breath sounds present, reduced overall, no adventitious sounds, no signs of respiratory distress, respiratory rate 19 saturation: 97% room air cardiac auscultation: regular heart rhythm, in 2 times, no murmurs heart rate: 8normal S1 and S2 per minute abdomen: globular, flaccid, bowel sounds, painless to superficial or deep palpation, no signs of peritoneal irritation. liver palpable 3 cm from the right costal margin, in the midclavicular line. extremities: warm and well perfused; capillary refill time less than 3 seconds; no edema or swelling of the calves. presence of ochre dermatitis on the lower limbs, with bilateral fibrous scars, without flapping pressure injury in the sacral region. discussed with [person]: we decided to discharge the patient after completing treatment for urinary tract infection by escherichia coli multis with a follow-up appointment visit on 1/17 at the gaf for reevaluation. we maintain medications in use during hospitalization. we provide guidance on warning signs. home care service sad for pressure injury care and home motor physiotherapy. good.

question: ᱤᱧ ᱱᱚᱣᱟ ᱠᱚᱨᱳᱱᱟ ᱵᱷᱟᱭᱨᱟᱥ ᱤᱫᱤ ᱠᱟᱛᱮᱧ ᱵᱚᱛᱚᱨᱚᱜ ᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱾

question: ᱪᱮᱫ ᱞᱮᱠᱟᱱ ᱡᱚᱛᱚᱱ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜ ᱞᱟᱹᱠᱛᱤ ?
answer: ᱟᱢ ᱫᱚ ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱵᱞᱚᱰ ᱥᱩᱜᱟᱨ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱟᱱᱟᱴ ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ ᱚᱲᱟᱜ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱥᱮᱵᱟ ᱟᱨ ᱚᱲᱟᱜ ᱨᱮ ᱢᱳᱴᱚᱨ ᱯᱷᱤᱡᱤᱭᱳᱛᱷᱮᱨᱟᱯᱤ ᱮᱢ ᱦᱟᱛᱟᱣ ᱫᱟᱲᱮᱭᱟᱜᱼᱟ ᱾ ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱑᱗ ᱟᱱᱟᱜ ᱵᱤᱰᱟᱹᱣ ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ ᱢᱤᱫᱴᱟᱝ ᱯᱷᱚᱞᱳᱼᱟᱯ ᱟᱯᱚᱭᱮᱱᱴᱢᱮᱱᱴ ᱦᱚᱸ ᱢᱮᱱᱟᱜᱼᱟ ᱾

question: ᱤᱧ ᱦᱟᱥᱯᱟᱛᱟᱞᱤᱧ ᱪᱟᱞᱟᱣ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾ ᱤᱧ ᱥᱟᱹᱨᱤᱜᱤᱧ ᱨᱩᱣᱟᱹ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ ?
answer: ᱱᱚᱣᱟ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱵᱷᱤᱛᱤᱨ ᱨᱮ ᱚᱡᱮ ᱫᱚ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜ ᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱵᱤᱱ ᱥᱟᱹᱨᱤ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱡᱚᱱᱚᱛᱟ ᱡᱟᱦᱟᱸ ᱫᱚ " ᱮᱴᱤᱭᱳᱞᱚᱡᱤ" ᱠᱟᱱᱟ, ᱮᱱᱠᱷᱟᱱ ᱮᱥᱯᱤᱨᱮᱥᱚᱱ ᱱᱤᱭᱩᱢᱳᱱᱤᱭᱟ ᱵᱟᱝᱠᱷᱟᱱ ᱦᱟᱭᱯᱳᱜᱞᱤᱥᱮᱢᱤᱭᱟ ᱦᱚᱸ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱫᱟᱲᱮᱭᱟᱜᱼᱟ ᱾

question: ᱛᱤᱱᱟᱹᱜ ᱜᱟᱱ ᱟᱢ ᱤᱧᱮᱢ ᱨᱟᱜᱟᱣ ᱟᱪᱚᱧᱟ ?
answer: ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱢᱟᱭᱟᱢ ᱨᱮ ᱨᱩᱣᱟᱹ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱤᱛᱤᱦᱟᱥ ᱛᱟᱦᱮᱸᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱾ ᱡᱤᱵᱽ ᱠᱟᱨᱵᱤᱱᱳᱥᱤᱥ ᱵᱟᱹᱛᱤᱞ ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ ᱵᱚᱞᱚ ᱠᱞᱟᱪᱟᱨ, ᱡᱤᱵᱽ ᱵᱟᱭᱳᱯᱥᱤ ᱟᱨ ᱥᱤᱴᱤ ᱥᱠᱮᱱ ᱠᱷᱚᱱ ᱰᱤᱯᱷᱨᱮᱱᱥᱤᱭᱟᱞ ᱠᱞᱟᱪᱟᱨ ᱡᱟᱣᱨᱟ ᱦᱩᱭᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾

years, chronic alcoholic, functionality: independent for basic activities, dependent for instrumental activities rankin 2, devices central venous catheter right internal jugular vein 05/10, orotracheal tube 05/10, indwelling urinary catheter 05/10, nasoenteral tube 05/10, antibiotics: current: meropenem 10/10 previous: ceftriaxone clindamycin d0 05/10 to 10/10 blood cultures 06/10: staphylococcus epidermidis 01 sample exams hospitalization: electroencephalogram 06/10: revealed abnormal, evidencing: moderate to marked diffuse disorganization of the background activity due to low amplitude of tracing rhythms, with a higher content of slow waves in the delta range, lack of physiological graphoelements of sleep, and absence of clinical and electroencephalographic reactivity to painful stimuli, however [person] presented spontaneous superficialization of consciousness during a short stretch of the tracing. electroclinical correlation: the findings are nonspecific and cannot rule out the effect of central nervous system depressant drugs. electroencephalogram 08/10: the marked symmetrical disorganization of the background activity due to diffuse and irregular slowing in the delta range, absence of physiological graphoelements of sleep and absence of electroencephalographic reactivity to painful stimuli noted intermittent modulation by low amplitude sinusoidal rhythms in the alpha/beta range. conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram is abnormal. the findings are compatible with the effect of central nervous system depressant drugs, and associated encephalopathy cannot be ruled out.
question: ᱪᱮᱫ ᱩᱱᱤ ᱵᱚᱞᱚᱰ ᱜᱨᱩᱯ ᱮ ᱧᱟᱢ ᱟᱠᱟᱫᱟ ?
answer: ᱳᱦ, ᱥᱤᱴᱤ ᱥᱠᱮᱱ ᱨᱮ ᱧᱮᱞᱚᱜ ᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱡᱮ ᱟᱢᱟᱜ ᱦᱤᱫᱽᱫᱤ ᱟᱨ ᱵᱚᱦᱚᱜ ᱨᱮ ᱒᱕% ᱟᱨᱴᱮᱨᱤᱭᱟᱞ ᱛᱷᱨᱚᱢᱵᱚᱥᱤᱥ ᱢᱮᱱᱟᱜᱼᱟ ᱾ ᱟᱢ ᱱᱤᱠᱳᱯᱟᱨᱤᱱ ᱧᱩᱛᱩᱢᱟᱱ ᱢᱤᱫᱴᱟᱝ ᱮᱱᱴᱤᱠᱳᱭᱜᱩᱞᱮᱱᱴ ᱛᱮ ᱪᱤᱠᱤᱪᱷᱟ ᱮᱛᱚᱦᱚᱵ ᱟᱠᱟᱫᱟᱢ ᱾

question: ᱵᱟᱝ ᱠᱷᱟᱱ ᱪᱮᱫ ᱱᱚᱣᱟ ᱫᱚ ᱢᱤᱫᱴᱟᱝ ᱥᱩᱪᱚᱠ ᱞᱮᱠᱟᱛᱮ ᱵᱟᱝ ᱦᱩᱭᱩᱜᱼᱟ ?
answer: ᱳᱦ, ᱟᱢᱮᱢ ᱦᱟᱦᱟᱲᱟᱜ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ, ᱩᱱᱤᱭᱟᱜ ᱥᱟᱸᱦᱮᱫ ᱦᱟᱛᱟᱣ ᱨᱮ ᱟᱱᱟᱴ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾ ᱯᱳᱭᱞᱳ ᱨᱮ, ᱱᱚᱨᱮᱯᱤᱱᱮᱯᱷᱨᱤᱱ ᱮᱢ ᱛᱟᱭᱚᱢ ᱩᱱᱤᱭᱟᱜ ᱵᱟᱹᱲᱤᱡ ᱵᱩᱡᱷᱟᱹᱣ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ, ᱛᱟᱭᱚᱢ ᱛᱮ ᱩᱱᱤᱭᱟᱜ ᱵᱨᱮᱰᱤᱠᱟᱨᱰᱤᱭᱟ (ᱦୃᱫᱚᱭ ᱨᱮᱭᱟᱜ ᱫᱷᱟᱹᱲ) ᱟᱨ ᱢᱤᱫᱴᱟᱝ ᱢᱟᱨᱟᱝ ᱥᱴᱨᱳᱠ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱾ ᱨᱟᱱ ᱵᱮᱵᱷᱟᱨ ᱛᱟᱭᱚᱢ, ᱩᱱᱤᱭᱟᱜ ᱤᱥᱠᱮᱢᱤᱠ ᱦᱟᱨᱴ ᱰᱤᱡᱤᱡ ᱟᱨ ᱢᱤᱫᱴᱟᱝ ᱥᱴᱨᱳᱠ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱞᱮᱱᱟ ᱡᱟᱦᱟᱸ ᱫᱚ ᱥᱟᱸᱦᱮᱫ ᱦᱟᱛᱟᱣ ᱨᱮ ᱟᱱᱟᱴ ᱮ ᱥᱤᱨᱡᱟᱹᱣ ᱞᱮᱫᱟ ᱾

influenza pcrs, critically ill myopathy, epigastric cellulitis secondary to resolved proning position, morbid obesity body mass index 54.67 kg/m2 systemic arterial hypertension, congenital divergent strabismus, marijuana user since age 13, social drinker admission weight 210 kg discharge weight 144 kg height 1.96 m. physical examination: good general condition, flushed, hydrated, anicteric, question: ᱤᱧ ᱪᱮᱫᱤᱧ ᱞᱟᱹᱲᱦᱟᱹᱭ ᱞᱮᱫᱟ ?
answer: ᱟᱢ ᱮᱱᱴᱤᱵᱟᱭᱳᱴᱤᱠ ᱮᱢ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ, ᱠᱞᱳᱥᱴᱨᱤᱰᱤᱭᱟᱢ ᱵᱤᱥ ᱞᱟᱹᱜᱤᱫ ᱵᱤᱰᱟᱹᱣ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱟᱨ ᱢᱮᱴᱨᱳᱱᱤᱰᱟᱡᱳᱞ ᱮᱢ ᱦᱩᱭ ᱟᱠᱟᱱᱟ ᱾
